column2: <ref>{{App|F1iii}}.</ref> the legendary creatures known among the [[Northmen]] and the [[Rohirrim]].

column1: The legend originated perhaps from the time when their ancestors
column2: the [[Éothéod]] saw and knew the Hobbits from the [[Vales of Anduin]]
column3: before or around their [[Wandering Days]]. From 'Holbytla' the word '[[Hobbits|Hobbit]]' in [[Westron]] was derived.<ref name="Road">{{TT|III8}}</ref>

column1: There is only one tale about them
column2: namely that they do not appear in any other tales. They do little
column3: and avoid the sight of men
column4: being able to vanish in a twinkling; and they can change their voices to resemble the piping of birds.

column1: When [[Théoden]] met [[Peregrin Took]] and [[Meriadoc Brandybuck]] standing guard at [[Isengard]] on [[5 March]]
column3: <ref>{{App|Great}}</ref> he immediately connected them to the folklore creature although he noted that they weren't known to [[Smoking|spout smoke]] from their mouths. He was corrected by Peregrin
column4: who said that they preferred the term "[[Hobbits|Hobbit]]"<ref name="Road"/> (''[[kuduk]]'').<ref name="Translation">{{App|F2}}</ref>

column1: ''Holbytla'' is the [[Old English]] translation of [[Rohan language|Rohirric]] ''[[Kûd-dûkan]]'' "hole-dweller"
column2: from which itself the word ''[[Kuduk]]'' was derived.<ref name="Translation"/>

column1: Holbytla seems to be a retroactive etymology
column3: which of course was initially a spontaneous inspiration by Tolkien without an explanation behind it.<ref>[[Humphrey Carpenter]]
